text: Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they would ask about the dose as well. So at any rate, to answer your question that the advise on the Metformin is if you have another reason to be on it. Patient: Yes. Doctor: For example, if you have a slight gluco-spasm where the glucose is a little bit elevated or if you have you know clinical type two diabetes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Then it may also be beneficial for your prostate cancer, but the prostate cancer I wouldn’t say should be the primary reason for being on it. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And if you do go back on that program, which it sounds like you’ve already done on your own. Patient: Yeah. text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It would be very different if the spot was in the bone. Bone metastasis takes a very long time to disappear. Sometimes you know a small one can take up to a year to disappear. So oftentimes when a cancer is involved, when they start the hormone therapy about three months later, a week later, two weeks later you talk to the radiation oncologist and by the time he starts the radiation planning which might be six to eight weeks later, the spot is still where he can see it, he can zap it and target that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And with a lymph node, uh if we start the hormone therapy even like a couple of weeks before that thing’s going to disappear; he won’t know what he’s targeting. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So all I’m saying is in theory that- Family Member: Right, Okay. Doctor: -combination that you just outlined kind of again makes sense, but I view it as to me the main purpose of doing the radio therapy would not be necessarily that you will have some sort of combined benefit in conjunction with the hormone therapy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It would be for the purpose of delaying the hormones that much longer. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: So I kind of view that as the primary motivation for doing that. But to me the primary motivation for radiation would be we’re doing something rather than just continue to observe you.

But to me the primary motivation for radiation would be we’re doing something rather than just continue to observe you.

text: Patient: So it’s going to be? Doctor: But up until now, it’s been this kind of almost called hit or miss, and just because of the way we did things in the U.S., it hasn’t. It’s been very frustrating. And I told you I went to Turkey to some little hospital taking care of this guy. We can give him We invented it. I can’t give it at my hospital. Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: So it’s been used in that way around the world but not, I’m not allowed to. Patient: That’s so tough. I see. Family Member: So it has pretty good results in Germany? Doctor: And so what they’ve done different than we do here is they report it on their experience. So they’re like we treated these six-hundred people, people with different stage, and different things, and they try to give some data about how the people live, what was their survival, and they showed you know tumor shrinking, and their response rate. And so overall that Gestalt, that’s a German word. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That looks, looks really good, I think. And then they collaborate with this gentleman that I have experience with in Turkey, seeing the data presented. I mean you share but you know some of the data that shows incredible responses to these. So I think part of it depends on how active your cancer is for this study, for this, this for the PSMA. Patient: Okay. Okay. Family Member: And then if you see the result, you would know probably in two months if you saw the results? Doctor: Yes.

So they’re like we treated these six-hundred people, people with different stage, and different things, and they try to give some data about how the people live, what was their survival, and they showed you know tumor shrinking, and their response rate. And then they collaborate with this gentleman that I have experience with in Turkey, seeing the data presented. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
